title: E95-1033

sentences.text: We provide a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora within the framework of a dependency-based grammar model .

Criteria for anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries rephrase major concepts from GB 's binding theory , while those for text-level anaphora incorporate an adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model .

Entity-a_unified_account_of_sentence-lev.label: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora
aliases: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora
Entity-a_unified_account_of_sentence-lev.description: A unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora refers to a comprehensive framework that integrates the resolution of anaphoric references within individual sentences and across larger text structures, utilizing principles from dependency-based grammar and adapting existing theories such as GB's binding theory and Grosz-Sidner's focus model.

mentions.local_name: a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora

Entity-grosz-sidner-style_focus_model.label: Grosz-Sidner-style focus model
aliases: adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model
Entity-grosz-sidner-style_focus_model.description: The Grosz-Sidner-style focus model is a theoretical framework used for understanding anaphora resolution in discourse, particularly focusing on how information is structured and referenced across sentences in a text.

mentions.local_name: adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model

Entity-major_concept.label: major concepts
Entity-major_concept.description: The term 'major concepts' refers to the fundamental ideas and principles derived from Government and Binding (GB) theory's binding theory, which are reinterpreted in the context of anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries.

Entity-dependency-based_grammar_model.label: dependency-based grammar model
Entity-dependency-based_grammar_model.description: A dependency-based grammar model is a linguistic framework that represents the grammatical structure of sentences through the relationships between words, focusing on the dependencies that exist between them.

Entity-gb_s_binding_theory.label: GB's binding theory
Entity-gb_s_binding_theory.description: GB's binding theory is a framework within generative grammar that addresses the syntactic and semantic principles governing the reference of pronouns and other anaphoric expressions in natural language.

Entity-text-level_anaphora.label: text-level anaphora
Entity-text-level_anaphora.description: Text-level anaphora refers to the linguistic phenomenon where expressions in a text refer back to previously mentioned entities or concepts within the same text, facilitating coherence and continuity in discourse.

Entity-binding_theory.label: binding theory
Entity-binding_theory.description: Binding theory is a linguistic theory that addresses the relationships between pronouns and the expressions with which they share reference, particularly focusing on the rules governing anaphora and reference in natural language.

Entity-anaphora_resolution.label: anaphora resolution
Entity-anaphora_resolution.description: Anaphora resolution is a linguistic process that involves determining the antecedent of an anaphoric expression within a given context, facilitating understanding of references in language.

Entity-major_concept_from_gb_s_binding_t.label: major concepts from GB's binding theory
aliases: major concepts from GB's binding theory
Entity-major_concept_from_gb_s_binding_t.description: The major concepts from GB's binding theory refer to the foundational principles and rules that govern the relationships between pronouns and their antecedents in the framework of generative grammar developed by Noam Chomsky.

mentions.local_name: major concepts from GB's binding theory

Entity-sentence_boundary.label: sentence boundaries
Entity-sentence_boundary.description: Sentence boundaries are the defined limits that separate individual sentences in written or spoken language, marking the end of one complete thought and the beginning of another.

Entity-anaphora.label: anaphora
Entity-anaphora.description: Anaphora is a linguistic phenomenon where a word or phrase refers back to another word or phrase earlier in the discourse, often used to avoid repetition.

summary: We provide a unified account of sentence-level and text-level anaphora within the framework of a dependency-based grammar model . Criteria for anaphora resolution within sentence boundaries rephrase major concepts from GB 's binding theory , while those for text-level anaphora incorporate an adapted version of a Grosz-Sidner-style focus model .

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship in which the subject offers, supplies, or makes available the object. It suggests that the subject is a source or means through which the object is obtained or realized, often implying a beneficial or supportive role in the context of the relationship.

Predicate-within_the_framework_of.label: within the framework of
Predicate-within_the_framework_of.description: The predicate 'within the framework of' indicates that the subject is being analyzed, understood, or developed in relation to a specific theoretical or conceptual structure represented by the object. It suggests that the subject's characteristics, principles, or phenomena are contextualized and interpreted through the lens of the framework provided by the object.

Predicate-rephrases.label: rephrases
Predicate-rephrases.description: The predicate 'rephrases' indicates a relationship where the subject reformulates or expresses the object in a different way, often to clarify, simplify, or provide an alternative perspective on the original content. This action involves taking the ideas or concepts represented by the object and presenting them anew through the lens of the subject, thereby enhancing understanding or emphasizing particular aspects.

Predicate-incorporates.label: incorporates
Predicate-incorporates.description: The predicate 'incorporates' signifies a relationship in which the subject integrates or includes elements, concepts, or features represented by the object into its structure or framework. This implies that the subject adopts or assimilates the characteristics of the object, thereby enhancing its functionality or comprehensiveness.

Predicate-are_relevant_for.label: are relevant for
Predicate-are_relevant_for.description: The predicate 'are relevant for' establishes a connection between the subject and the object by indicating that the subject has significance, importance, or applicability in relation to the object. It suggests that the subject contributes to, influences, or is necessary for understanding, addressing, or analyzing the object in some meaningful way.

Predicate-rephrase.label: rephrase
Predicate-rephrase.description: The predicate 'rephrase' indicates a transformation or restatement of the subject into a different form or expression that conveys the same or similar meaning as the object. It suggests a process of rewording or altering the structure of the subject to enhance clarity, understanding, or to align with specific conceptual frameworks represented by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship where the subject represents a specific concept or instance that falls under a more general category or concept denoted by the object. This relationship implies that the subject is a subset or a specific example of the broader term, which encompasses a wider range of related ideas or phenomena.
